citation.article-title: Micavibrio admirandus gen. et sp. nov.

p.s: Micavibrio (from the Latin noun, mica, a crumb and the masculine noun, vibrio, designating genus in scientific Latin. Micavibrio, a masculine noun, very small vibration).
The cells are rod-shaped, curved, small, and single, with one polar sheathless flagellum in the motile stage.
The bacterial cells attach themselves to the cells of the host bacteria and develop as exoparasites that cause lysis of the host cells.
There may be a certain degree of specificity to a number of possible host bacteria.
The GC content of the DNA of the strain studied was 57.1 M%.
The strain was isolated from waste water.
The type species is M. admirandus, sp. nov.
